channel.title: IT-Security & Privacy News Aggregator
channel.description: Aggregierter RSS-Feed aus führenden IT-Security, Privacy und Cyber Policy Quellen

item.title: Iranian Infy APT Resurfaces with New Malware Activity After Years of Silence
item.description: Threat hunters have discerned new activity associated with an Iranian threat actor known as Infy (aka Prince of Persia), nearly five years after the hacking group was observed targeting victims in Sweden, the Netherlands, and Turkey. "The scale of Prince of Persia's activity is more significant than we originally anticipated," Tomer Bar, vice president of security research at SafeBreach, said
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: U.S. DOJ Charges 54 in ATM Jackpotting Scheme Using Ploutus Malware
item.description: The U.S. Department of Justice (DoJ) this week announced the indictment of 54 individuals in connection with a multi-million dollar ATM jackpotting scheme. The large-scale conspiracy involved deploying malware named Ploutus to hack into automated teller machines (ATMs) across the U.S. and force them to dispense cash. The indicted members are alleged to be part of Tren de Aragua (TdA, Spanish for
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Friday Squid Blogging: Petting a Squid
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Cisco VPNs, Email Services Hit in Separate Threat Campaigns
item.description: The company suffered one sophisticated five-alarm campaign and one messy spray-and-pray attack, mere days apart.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: Russia-Linked Hackers Use Microsoft 365 Device Code Phishing for Account Takeovers
item.description: A suspected Russia-aligned group has been attributed to a phishing campaign that employs device code authentication workflows to steal victims' Microsoft 365 credentials and conduct account takeover attacks. The activity, ongoing since September 2025, is being tracked by Proofpoint under the moniker UNK_AcademicFlare. The attacks involve using compromised email addresses belonging to government
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Microsoft 365 accounts targeted in wave of OAuth phishing attacks
State-linked and criminal hackers use device code phishing against M365 users
LongNosedGoblin Caught Snooping on Asian Governments
item.description: New China-aligned APT group is deploying Group Policy to sniff through government networks across Southeast Asia and Japan.
item.dc:creator: Becky Bracken

item.title: Cracked Software and YouTube Videos Spread CountLoader and GachiLoader Malware
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of a new campaign that has used cracked software distribution sites as a distribution vector for a new version of a modular and stealthy loader known as CountLoader. The campaign "uses CountLoader as the initial tool in a multistage attack for access, evasion, and delivery of additional malware families," Cyderes Howler Cell Threat Intelligence
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Dismantling Defenses: Trump 2.0 Cyber Year in Review
item.description: The Trump administration has pursued a staggering range of policy pivots this past year that threaten to weaken the nation’s ability and willingness to address a broad spectrum of technology challenges, from cybersecurity and privacy to countering disinformation, fraud and corruption. These shifts, along with the president’s efforts to restrict free speech and freedom of the press, have come at such a rapid clip that many readers probably aren’t even aware of them all.
item.dc:creator: BrianKrebs

item.title: Identity Fraud Among Home-Care Workers Puts Patients at Risk
item.description: Reports of patients being cared for by unqualified home-care aides with fake identities continue to emerge, highlighting a need for more stringent identity authentication.
item.dc:creator: Arielle Waldman

item.title: OWASP Drops First AI Agent Risk List
item.description: <p>These aren't simple chatbots anymore—these AI agents access data and tools and carry out tasks, making them infinitely more capable and dangerous.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-owasp-ai-agent-risk-list/">OWASP Drops First AI Agent Risk List</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: A Cybersecurity Playbook for AI Adoption
item.description: AI adds real value to cybersecurity today, but it cannot yet serve as a single security guardian. Here's how organizations can safely combine AI-driven analysis with deterministic rules and proven security practices.
item.dc:creator: Dirk Schrader

item.title: A Good Year for North Korean Cybercriminals
item.description: North Korea shifted its strategy to patiently target &quot;bigger fish&quot; for larger payouts, using sophisticated methods to execute attacks at opportune times.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: UK Foreign Office Cyber Breach Exposed Diplomatic Secrets
item.description: <p>The government stopped short of directly attributing the attack to Chinese operatives or the Chinese state.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-uk-foreign-office-cyber-breach/">UK Foreign Office Cyber Breach Exposed Diplomatic Secrets</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: Denmark Blames Russia for "Destructive" Cyber-Attacks
item.description: The Danish intelligence service believes some pro-Russian hacktivist groups have links with the Kremlin

item.title: AI Advertising Company Hacked
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: WatchGuard Warns of Active Exploitation of Critical Fireware OS VPN Vulnerability
item.description: WatchGuard has released fixes to address a critical security flaw in Fireware OS that it said has been exploited in real-world attacks. Tracked as CVE-2025-14733 (CVSS score: 9.3), the vulnerability has been described as a case of out-of-bounds write affecting the iked process that could allow a remote unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary code. "This vulnerability affects both the
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: US Charges 54 in Massive ATM Jackpotting Conspiracy
item.description: The US has charged 54 individuals in a massive ATM jackpotting conspiracy linked to Venezuelan crime syndicate Tren de Aragua, accused of stealing millions

item.title: Nigeria Arrests RaccoonO365 Phishing Developer Linked to Microsoft 365 Attacks
item.description: Authorities in Nigeria have announced the arrest of three "high-profile internet fraud suspects" who are alleged to have been involved in phishing attacks targeting major corporations, including the main developer behind the RaccoonO365 phishing-as-a-service (PhaaS) scheme. The Nigeria Police Force National Cybercrime Centre (NPF–NCCC) said investigations conducted in collaboration with
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: FBI Disrupts Russian Crypto Laundering Hub Enabling Cybercrime
item.description: A 39-year-old Russian national is accused of working with cybercriminals to convert criminal proceeds from cryptocurrency into various cash currencies

item.title: New UEFI Flaw Enables Early-Boot DMA Attacks on ASRock, ASUS, GIGABYTE, MSI Motherboards
item.description: Certain motherboard models from vendors like ASRock, ASUSTeK Computer, GIGABYTE, and MSI are affected by a security vulnerability that leaves them susceptible to early-boot direct memory access (DMA) attacks across architectures that implement a Unified Extensible Firmware Interface (UEFI) and input–output memory management unit (IOMMU). UEFI and IOMMU are designed to enforce a security
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Italian Ferry Malware Attack Sparks International Probe
item.description: <p>French intelligence agencies uncovered what appears to be a coordinated foreign interference operation targeting the GNV Fantastic.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-italian-ferry-malware-attack/">Italian Ferry Malware Attack Sparks International Probe</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: Cybersecurity Predictions for 2026: Human Risk, AI Data Leaks, and the Next Big Breach | UpGuard
item.description: Get one step ahead of the next big shock. Four security predictions for 2026—likely, uncomfortable, and easy to miss.

item.title: SonicWall Edge Access Devices Hit by Zero-Day Attacks
item.description: In the latest attacks against the vendor's SMA1000 devices, threat actors have chained a new zero-day flaw with a critical vulnerability disclosed earlier this year.
item.dc:creator: Rob Wright

item.title: OAuth Device Code Phishing Campaigns Surge Targets Microsoft 365
item.description: A surge in phishing attacks exploiting Microsoft’s OAuth device code flow has been identified by Proofpoint

item.title: HPE OneView Flaw Rated CVSS 10.0 Allows Unauthenticated Remote Code Execution
item.description: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) has resolved a maximum-severity security flaw in OneView Software that, if successfully exploited, could result in remote code execution. The critical vulnerability, assigned the CVE identifier CVE-2025-37164, carries a CVSS score of 10.0. HPE OneView is an IT infrastructure management software that streamlines IT operations and controls all systems via a
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: ThreatsDay Bulletin: WhatsApp Hijacks, MCP Leaks, AI Recon, React2Shell Exploit and 15 More Stories
item.description: This week’s ThreatsDay Bulletin tracks how attackers keep reshaping old tools and finding new angles in familiar systems. Small changes in tactics are stacking up fast, and each one hints at where the next big breach could come from. From shifting infrastructures to clever social hooks, the week’s activity shows just how fluid the threat landscape has become. Here’s the full rundown of what
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: North Korea-Linked Hackers Steal $2.02 Billion in 2025, Leading Global Crypto Theft
item.description: Threat actors with ties to the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (DPRK or North Korea) have been instrumental in driving a surge in global cryptocurrency theft in 2025, accounting for at least $2.02 billion out of more than $3.4 billion stolen from January through early December. The figure represents a 51% increase year-over-year and $681 million more than 2024, when the threat actors stole
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Dormant Iran APT is Still Alive, Spying on Dissidents
item.description: &quot;Prince of Persia&quot; has rewritten the rules of persistence with advanced operational security and cryptographic communication with its command-and-control server.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: North Korea Steals Over $2bn in Crypto in 2025
item.description: Chainalysis warns North Korea continues to steal billions in crypto for its weapons program

item.title: New BeaverTail Malware Variant Linked to Lazarus Group
item.description: A new variant of the BeaverTail malware linked to North Korean hackers has been identified targeting cryptocurrency traders and developers

item.title: The Case for Dynamic AI-SaaS Security as Copilots Scale
item.description: Within the past year, artificial intelligence copilots and agents have quietly permeated the SaaS applications businesses use every day. Tools like Zoom, Slack, Microsoft 365, Salesforce, and ServiceNow now come with built-in AI assistants or agent-like features. Virtually every major SaaS vendor has rushed to embed AI into their offerings. The result is an explosion of AI capabilities across
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Microsoft December Update Breaks Critical IIS Servers
item.description: <p>The security updates delivered through KB5071546 have fundamentally broken Message Queuing (MSMQ) functionality across multiple Windows versions.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-microsoft-critical-iis-servers/">Microsoft December Update Breaks Critical IIS Servers</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: LongNosedGoblin tries to sniff out governmental affairs in Southeast Asia and Japan
item.description: ESET researchers discovered a China-aligned APT group, LongNosedGoblin, which uses Group Policy to deploy cyberespionage tools across networks of governmental institutions

item.title: HMRC Warns of Over 135,000 Scam Reports
item.description: The UK’s tax office has received 135,500 reports of suspected scams in the past 10 months including 4800 related to self assessment filings

item.title: Chinese Hackers Target Cisco’s Email Security Systems
item.description: <p>The Chinese threat group, tracked as UAT-9686, has deployed a collection of custom-built hacking tools to maintain persistent access to compromised systems.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-cisco-email-security-breach/">Chinese Hackers Target Cisco’s Email Security Systems</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: SoundCloud Cyberattack Leaves 28M Users Exposed
item.description: <p>The breach has already triggered widespread chaos across the platform, with users worldwide reporting connection failures and cryptic error messages.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-soundcloud-cyberattack/">SoundCloud Cyberattack Leaves 28M Users Exposed</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: Kimsuky Spreads DocSwap Android Malware via QR Phishing Posing as Delivery App
item.description: The North Korean threat actor known as Kimsuky has been linked to a new campaign that distributes a new variant of Android malware called DocSwap via QR codes hosted on phishing sites mimicking Seoul-based logistics firm CJ Logistics (formerly CJ Korea Express). "The threat actor leveraged QR codes and notification pop-ups to lure victims into installing and executing the malware on their mobile
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: CISA Flags Critical ASUS Live Update Flaw After Evidence of Active Exploitation
item.description: The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) on Wednesday added a critical flaw impacting ASUS Live Update to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, citing evidence of active exploitation. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-59374 (CVSS score: 9.3), has been described as an "embedded malicious code vulnerability" introduced by means of a supply chain compromise
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Cisco Warns of Active Attacks Exploiting Unpatched 0-Day in AsyncOS Email Security Appliances
item.description: Cisco has alerted users to a maximum-severity zero-day flaw in Cisco AsyncOS software that has been actively exploited by a China-nexus advanced persistent threat (APT) actor codenamed UAT-9686 in attacks targeting Cisco Secure Email Gateway and Cisco Secure Email and Web Manager. The networking equipment major said it became aware of the intrusion campaign on December 10, 2025, and that it
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Critical Fortinet Flaws Under Active Attack
item.description: Attackers are targeting admin accounts, and once authenticated, exporting device configurations including hashed credentials and other sensitive information.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: In Cybersecurity, Claude Leaves Other LLMs in the Dust
item.description: Anthropic proves that LLMs can be fairly resistant to abuse. Most developers are either incapable of building safer tools, or unwilling to invest in doing so.
item.dc:creator: Nate Nelson, Contributing Writer

item.title: 'Cellik' Android RAT Leverages Google Play Store
item.description: The remote access Trojan lets an attacker remotely control a victim's phone and can generate malicious apps from inside the Play Store.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Securing the Network Edge: A Comprehensive Framework for Modern Cybersecurity
item.description: The future of cybersecurity means defending everywhere. Securing IoT, cloud, and remote work requires a unified edge-to-cloud strategy. (First in a three-part series.)
item.dc:creator: George V. Hulme, Contributing Writer

item.title: 'Fake Proof' and AI Slop Hobble Defenders
item.description: In the React2Shell saga, nonworking and trivial proof-of-concept exploits led to confusion and perhaps a false sense of security. Can the onslaught of PoCs be tamed?
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: The Future of Quantum-Safe Networks Depends on Interoperable Standards
item.description: As quantum computing advances, secure, interoperable standards will be critical to making quantum key distribution (QKD) practical, trusted, and future-proof.
item.dc:creator: Martin Ward

item.title: SonicWall Fixes Actively Exploited CVE-2025-40602 in SMA 100 Appliances
item.description: SonicWall has rolled out fixes to address a security flaw in Secure Mobile Access (SMA) 100 series appliances that it said has been actively exploited in the wild. The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-40602 (CVSS score: 6.6), concerns a case of local privilege escalation that arises as a result of insufficient authorization in the appliance management console (AMC). It affects the following
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Kimwolf Botnet Hijacks 1.8 Million Android TVs, Launches Large-Scale DDoS Attacks
item.description: A new distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) botnet known as Kimwolf has enlisted a massive army of no less than 1.8 million infected devices comprising Android-based TVs, set-top boxes, and tablets, and may be associated with another botnet known as AISURU, according to findings from QiAnXin XLab. "Kimwolf is a botnet compiled using the NDK [Native Development Kit]," the company said in a report
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Three ways teams can tackle Iran’s tangled web of state-sponsored espionage
Motors WordPress Vulnerability Exposes Sites to Takeover
item.description: A critical flaw in the Motors WordPress theme affecting more than 20,000 installations allows low-privileged users to gain full control of websites

item.title: Attackers Use Stolen AWS Credentials in Cryptomining Campaign
item.description: Threat actors wielding stolen AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) credentials leverage Amazon EC and EC2 infrastructure across multiple customer environments.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: New “Lies-in-the-Loop” Attack Undermines AI Safety Dialogs
item.description: A novel attack technique dubbed ”Lies-in-the-Loop” (LITL) has been observed manipulating human approval prompts in agentic AI systems

item.title: APT28 Targets Ukrainian UKR-net Users in Long-Running Credential Phishing Campaign
item.description: The Russian state-sponsored threat actor known as APT28 has been attributed to what has been described as a "sustained" credential-harvesting campaign targeting users of UKR[.]net, a webmail and news service popular in Ukraine. The activity, observed by Recorded Future's Insikt Group between June 2024 and April 2025, builds upon prior findings from the cybersecurity company in May 2024 that
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: New ForumTroll Phishing Attacks Target Russian Scholars Using Fake eLibrary Emails
item.description: The threat actor linked to Operation ForumTroll has been attributed to a fresh set of phishing attacks targeting individuals within Russia, according to Kaspersky. The Russian cybersecurity vendor said it detected the new activity in October 2025. The origins of the threat actor are presently unknown. "While the spring cyberattacks focused on organizations, the fall campaign honed in on
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: ISACA Named Global Credentialing Authority for DoD’s CMMC Program
item.description: ISACA has been appointed by the US DoD as the global credentialing authority for its CMMC program

item.title: Deliberate Internet Shutdowns
item.description: <p>For <a href="https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c0jq2q5jnw3o">two days</a> in September, Afghanistan had <a href="https://ioda.inetintel.cc.gatech.edu/country/AF?from=1759067186&#38;until=1759326386&#38;view=view1">no internet</a>. No satellite failed; no cable was cut. This was a deliberate outage, mandated by the Taliban government. It followed a more localized shutdown two weeks prior, reportedly instituted &#8220;to prevent immoral activities.&#8221; No additional explanation was given. The timing couldn&#8217;t have been worse: communities still reeling from a major earthquake <a href="https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/afghanistans-cellphone-internet-services-down-monitoring-shows-2025-09-30/">lost emergency communications</a>, <a href="https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cdxqdy5nrlqo">flights were grounded</a>, and <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2025/10/03/asia/afghanistan-internet-shutdown-intl-hnk-dst">banking was interrupted</a>. Afghanistan&#8217;s blackout is part of a wider pattern. Just since the end of September, there were also major nationwide internet shutdowns in ...</p>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Top 10 Security Events of 2025 | UpGuard
item.description: Recap the ten most impactful events that reshaped the cybersecurity industry this year and the critical lessons each had to teach us. Read more here.

item.title: Fix SOC Blind Spots: See Threats to Your Industry & Country in Real Time
item.description: Modern security teams often feel like they’re driving through fog with failing headlights. Threats accelerate, alerts multiply, and SOCs struggle to understand which dangers matter right now for their business. Breaking out of reactive defense is no longer optional. It’s the difference between preventing incidents and cleaning up after them. Below is the path from reactive firefighting to a
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: China-Linked Ink Dragon Hacks Governments Using ShadowPad and FINALDRAFT Malware
item.description: The threat actor known as Jewelbug has been increasingly focusing on government targets in Europe since July 2025, even as it continues to attack entities located in Southeast Asia and South America. Check Point Research is tracking the cluster under the name Ink Dragon. It's also referenced by the broader cybersecurity community under the names CL-STA-0049, Earth Alux, and REF7707. The
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: US Autoparts Maker LKQ Confirms Oracle EBS Breach
item.description: LKQ confirmed that over 9000 individuals saw their personal data compromised because of the breach

item.title: European Investigators Disrupt $12m Call Center Fraud Ring
item.description: Eurojust reveals new policing operation which helped to smash a Ukraine-based call center fraud gang

item.title: GhostPoster Malware Found in 17 Firefox Add-ons with 50,000+ Downloads
item.description: A new campaign named GhostPoster has leveraged logo files associated with 17 Mozilla Firefox browser add-ons to embed malicious JavaScript code designed to hijack affiliate links, inject tracking code, and commit click and ad fraud. The extensions have been collectively downloaded over 50,000 times, according to Koi Security, which discovered the campaign. The add-ons are no longer available.
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Afripol Focuses on Regional Cyber Challenges, Deepening Cooperation
item.description: Rapid digitization, uneven cybersecurity know-how, and growing cybercriminal syndicates in the region have challenged law enforcement and prosecutors.
item.dc:creator: Robert Lemos, Contributing Writer

item.title: Why a 17-Year-Old Built an AI Model to Expose Deepfake Maps
item.description: A high-school student is tackling the overlooked risk of AI-generated satellite imagery that could mislead governments and emergency responders.
item.dc:creator: Joan Goodchild

item.title: Why You Should Train Your SOC Like a Triathlete
item.description: The key elements in a security operations center's strategy map align closely to the swim/bike/run events in a triathlon. SOCs, like triathletes, perform well when their &quot;inputs&quot; are strong.
item.dc:creator: Brian Dye

item.title: Venezuelan Oil Company Downplays Alleged US Cyberattack
item.description: But media reports described the attack as causing major disruption to PDVSA, the state-owned oil and natural gas company.
item.dc:creator: Jai Vijayan, Contributing Writer

item.title: Russia Hits Critical Orgs Via Misconfigured Edge Devices
item.description: Amazon detailed a long-running campaign by Russia against critical infrastructure organizations, particularly in the energy sector.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Compromised IAM Credentials Power a Large AWS Crypto Mining Campaign
item.description: An ongoing campaign has been observed targeting Amazon Web Services (AWS) customers using compromised Identity and Access Management (IAM) credentials to enable cryptocurrency mining. The activity, first detected by Amazon's GuardDuty managed threat detection service and its automated security monitoring systems on November 2, 2025, employs never-before-seen persistence techniques to hamper
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Browser Extension Harvests 8M Users' AI Chatbot Data
item.description: Urban VPN Proxy, which claims to protect users' privacy, collects data from conversations with ChatGPT, Claude, Gemini, Copilot, and other AI assistants.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: Rogue NuGet Package Poses as Tracer.Fody, Steals Cryptocurrency Wallet Data
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have discovered a new malicious NuGet package that typosquats and impersonates the popular .NET tracing library and its author to sneak in a cryptocurrency wallet stealer. The malicious package, named "Tracer.Fody.NLog," remained on the repository for nearly six years. It was published by a user named "csnemess" on February 26, 2020. It masquerades as "Tracer.Fody,"
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Enterprises Gear Up Ahead of 2026's IT Transformation Shift
item.description: Experts predict big changes are coming for IT infrastructure in 2026, driven by AI adoption, hybrid cloud strategies, and evolving security demands.
item.dc:creator: Arielle Waldman

item.title: Most Parked Domains Now Serving Malicious Content
item.description: Direct navigation -- the act of visiting a website by manually typing a domain name in a web browser -- has never been riskier: A new study finds the vast majority of "parked" domains -- mostly expired or dormant domain names, or common misspellings of popular websites -- are now configured to redirect visitors to sites that foist scams and malware.
item.dc:creator: BrianKrebs

item.title: Amazon Exposes Years-Long GRU Cyber Campaign Targeting Energy and Cloud Infrastructure
item.description: Amazon's threat intelligence team has disclosed details of a "years-long" Russian state-sponsored campaign that targeted Western critical infrastructure between 2021 and 2025. Targets of the campaign included energy sector organizations across Western nations, critical infrastructure providers in North America and Europe, and entities with cloud-hosted network infrastructure. The activity has
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Chinese Surveillance and AI
item.description: <p>New report: &#8220;<a href="https://aspi.s3.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/11/27122307/The-partys-AI-How-Chinas-new-AI-systems-are-reshaping-human-rights.pdf">The Party&#8217;s AI: How China&#8217;s New AI Systems are Reshaping Human Rights</a>.&#8221; From a <a href="https://www.aspi.org.au/report/the-partys-ai-how-chinas-new-ai-systems-are-reshaping-human-rights/">summary article</a>:</p> <blockquote><p>China is already the world&#8217;s largest exporter of AI powered surveillance technology; new surveillance technologies and platforms developed in China are also not likely to simply stay there. By exposing the full scope of China&#8217;s AI driven control apparatus, this report presents clear, evidence based insights for policymakers, civil society, the media and technology companies seeking to counter the rise of AI enabled repression and human rights violations, and China&#8217;s growing efforts to project that repression beyond its borders...</p></blockquote>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: Why Data Security and Privacy Need to Start in Code
item.description: AI-assisted coding and AI app generation platforms have created an unprecedented surge in software development. Companies are now facing rapid growth in both the number of applications and the pace of change within those applications. Security and privacy teams are under significant pressure as the surface area they must cover is expanding quickly while their staffing levels remain largely
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Fortinet FortiGate Under Active Attack Through SAML SSO Authentication Bypass
item.description: Threat actors have begun to exploit two newly disclosed security flaws in Fortinet FortiGate devices, less than a week after public disclosure. Cybersecurity company Arctic Wolf said it observed active intrusions involving malicious single sign-on (SSO) logins on FortiGate appliances on December 12, 2025. The attacks exploit two critical authentication bypasses (CVE-2025-59718 and CVE-2025-59719
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Google to Kill Popular Dark Web Report Tool
item.description: <p>This marks another abrupt end to a Google service that users had come to rely on. </p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-google-kills-dark-web-report-tool/">Google to Kill Popular Dark Web Report Tool</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: ESET Threat Report H2 2025
item.description: A view of the H2 2025 threat landscape as seen by ESET telemetry and from the perspective of ESET threat detection and research experts

item.title: Coupang CEO Quits After Breach Hits 33.7M South Koreans
item.description: <p>The e-commerce firm's data breach exposed nearly two-thirds of the entire country's population after hackers operated undetected for five months.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-coupang-ceo-quits/">Coupang CEO Quits After Breach Hits 33.7M South Koreans</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: TechRepublic Staff

item.title: React2Shell Vulnerability Actively Exploited to Deploy Linux Backdoors
item.description: The security vulnerability known as React2Shell is being exploited by threat actors to deliver malware families like KSwapDoor and ZnDoor, according to findings from Palo Alto Networks Unit 42 and NTT Security. "KSwapDoor is a professionally engineered remote access tool designed with stealth in mind," Justin Moore, senior manager of threat intel research at Palo Alto Networks Unit 42, said in a
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Google to Shut Down Dark Web Monitoring Tool in February 2026
item.description: Google has announced that it's discontinuing its dark web report tool in February 2026, less than two years after it was launched as a way for users to monitor if their personal information is found on the dark web. To that end, scans for new dark web breaches will be stopped on January 15, 2026, and the feature will cease to exist effective February 16, 2026. "While the report offered general
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: How Cyber Insurance MGAs Shape Policies for Evolving Cyber-Risks
item.description: Managing general agents help insurers navigate sectors where they lack expertise. A cybersecurity policy written by an MGA is more likely to reflect an understanding of the risks CISOs deal with.
item.dc:creator: Ericka Chickowski, Contributing Writer

item.title: Apple Patches More Zero-Days Used in 'Sophisticated' Attack
item.description: Two Apple zero-day vulnerabilities discovered this month have overlap with another mysterious zero-day flaw Google patched last week.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Culafi

item.title: Think Like an Attacker: Cybersecurity Tips From a CISO
item.description: Etay Maor, a cybersecurity strategist and professor, shares his journey, insights, and advice on breaking into the diverse and ever-evolving field of cybersecurity.
item.dc:creator: Kristina Beek

item.title: Featured Chrome Browser Extension Caught Intercepting Millions of Users' AI Chats
item.description: A Google Chrome extension with a "Featured" badge and six million users has been observed silently gathering every prompt entered by users into artificial intelligence (AI)-powered chatbots like OpenAI ChatGPT, Anthropic Claude, Microsoft Copilot, DeepSeek, Google Gemini, xAI Grok, Meta AI, and Perplexity. The extension in question is Urban VPN Proxy, which has a 4.7 rating on the Google Chrome
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Flaw in Hacktivist Ransomware Lets Victims Decrypt Own Files
item.description: A new version of VolkLocker, wielded by the pro-Russia RaaS group CyberVolk, has some key enhancements but one fatal flaw.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Montalbano, Contributing Writer

item.title: Meet the Council’s New Client Engagement Operations Director
item.dc:creator: amalone@pcisecuritystandards.org (Alicia Malone)

item.title: FreePBX Patches Critical SQLi, File-Upload, and AUTHTYPE Bypass Flaws Enabling RCE
item.description:
Multiple security vulnerabilities have been disclosed in the open-source private branch exchange (PBX) platform FreePBX, including a critical flaw that could result in an authentication bypass under certain configurations. The shortcomings, discovered by Horizon3.ai and reported to the project maintainers on September 15, 2025, are listed below -
CVE-2025-61675 (CVSS score: 8.6) - Numerous
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: ⚡ Weekly Recap: Apple 0-Days, WinRAR Exploit, LastPass Fines, .NET RCE, OAuth Scams & More
item.description: If you use a smartphone, browse the web, or unzip files on your computer, you are in the crosshairs this week. Hackers are currently exploiting critical flaws in the daily software we all rely on—and in some cases, they started attacking before a fix was even ready. Below, we list the urgent updates you need to install right now to stop these active threats. ⚡ Threat of the Week Apple and
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Against the Federal Moratorium on State-Level Regulation of AI
item.description: <p>Cast your mind back to May of this year: Congress was in the throes of debate over the massive <a href="https://www.congress.gov/bill/119th-congress/house-bill/1">budget bill</a>. Amidst the many seismic provisions, Senator Ted Cruz <a href="https://iapp.org/news/a/policy-analysis-us-house-committee-seeks-moratorium-on-state-AI-rules">dropped</a> a ticking time bomb of tech policy: a ten-year moratorium on the ability of states to regulate artificial intelligence. To many, this was catastrophic. The few massive AI companies seem to be swallowing our economy whole: their energy demands are overriding household needs, their data demands are overriding creators&#8217; copyright, and their products are triggering mass unemployment as well as new types of clinical ...</p>
item.dc:creator: Bruce Schneier

item.title: A Browser Extension Risk Guide After the ShadyPanda Campaign
item.description: In early December 2025, security researchers exposed a cybercrime campaign that had quietly hijacked popular Chrome and Edge browser extensions on a massive scale. A threat group dubbed ShadyPanda spent seven years playing the long game, publishing or acquiring harmless extensions, letting them run clean for years to build trust and gain millions of installs, then suddenly flipping them into
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Apple Releases macOS Sequoia 15.7.3 Security Update
item.description: <p>Apple has released macOS Sequoia 15.7.3 with important security fixes. Here’s what to know before installing the update.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-apple-macos-sequoia-security-update/">Apple Releases macOS Sequoia 15.7.3 Security Update</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>

item.title: Are Your AI Assistants Under Attack?
item.description: <p>Many users utilize an AI assistant to handle their inbox, leaving them vulnerable to attack. </p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-ai-assistants-under-attack/">Are Your AI Assistants Under Attack?</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>
item.dc:creator: Drew Robb

item.title: Phantom Stealer Spread by ISO Phishing Emails Hitting Russian Finance Sector
item.description: Cybersecurity researchers have disclosed details of an active phishing campaign that's targeting a wide range of sectors in Russia with phishing emails that deliver Phantom Stealer via malicious ISO optical disc images. The activity, codenamed Operation MoneyMount-ISO by Seqrite Labs, has primarily singled out finance and accounting entities, with those in the procurement, legal, payroll
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: ServiceNow Mulls $7B Armis Cybersecurity Acquisition
item.description: <p>The deal could be announced within days, according to Bloomberg.</p> <p>The post <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com/article/news-servicenow-armis-deal/">ServiceNow Mulls $7B Armis Cybersecurity Acquisition</a> appeared first on <a href="https://www.techrepublic.com">TechRepublic</a>.</p>

item.title: VolkLocker Ransomware Exposed by Hard-Coded Master Key Allowing Free Decryption
item.description: The pro-Russian hacktivist group known as CyberVolk (aka GLORIAMIST) has resurfaced with a new ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) offering called VolkLocker that suffers from implementation lapses in test artifacts, allowing users to decrypt files without paying an extortion fee. According to SentinelOne, VolkLocker (aka CyberVolk 2.x) emerged in August 2025 and is capable of targeting both Windows
item.dc:creator: info@thehackernews.com (The Hacker News)

item.title: Understanding and Mitigating CVE-2025-55182 (React2Shell) | UpGuard
item.description: CVE-2025-55182 is a critical unauthenticated RCE in React Server Components (CVSS 10.0). Check if your Next.js or React 19 app is vulnerable and patch now.
